title: NSA document on targeting Five Eyes countries and territories
description: This document states that the National Security Agency is prohibited from conducting foreign surveillance on the "Five Eyes" countries, which include U.S. allies Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom, or their territories.
tags: Judge John Bates, FISA court, foreign intelligence surveillance act, FISA, NSA, National Security Agency

title: DNI, attorney general certify surveillance targets 'reasonably believed' to be outside U.S.
description: In this document, the director of national intelligence and the attorney general certify that there are procedures in place to ensure that surveillance conducted under Section 702 of the FISA Amendments Act will be limited to targeting people "reasonably believed to be located outside the United States." They state that the foreign intelligence to be collected "concerns foreign powers" as defined by statute. The list of foreign powers is in Exhibit F.
tags: Judge John Bates, FISA court, foreign intelligence surveillance act, FISA, NSA, National Security Agency

title: FISA Amendments Act of 2008 Section 702 summary document
description: This document summarizes the way the law works and describes the three types of certifications used to permit the surveillance, as well as targeting and minimization procedures. The three certification are for foreign governments, counterterrorism and WMD/proliferation.
tags: Judge John Bates, FISA court, foreign intelligence surveillance act, FISA, NSA, National Security Agency

title: NSA director Keith Alexander's Affidavit Regarding Spying on Foreign Entities
description: The affidavit was submitted in support of the 2010 certification concerning foreign governments, factions and other entities. In it, Alexander states that pursuant to the certification, NSA seeks to acquire foreign intelligence information concerning foreign powers. The list of foreign powers is in Exhibit F.
tags: Judge John Bates, FISA court, foreign intelligence surveillance act, FISA, NSA, National Security Agency

title: FISA Judge's Order Authorizing Surveillance of Foreign Entities
description: With this order dated Aug. 19, 2010, John D. Bates, then-Chief Judge of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, approved an annual certification permitting the National Security Agency to conduct surveillance about 193 foreign governments, foreign factions, foreign-based political organizations and foreign entities such as the World Bank. Each year, a new certification must be approved by the court to permit such surveillance under Section 702 of the FISA Amendments Act.
tags: Judge John Bates, FISA court, foreign intelligence surveillance act, FISA, NSA, National Security Agency

title: COP15 Interception Document
description: At the Copenhagen Climate Summit in 2009, the world's nations were supposed to reach an agreement that would protect future generations against catastrophic climate change. But not everyone was playing by the rules. A leaked document now reveals that the US employed the NSA, its signals intelligence agency, to intercept information about other countries' views on the climate negotiations before and during the summit. According to observers, the spying may have contributed to the Americans getting their way in the negotiations

title: AIVD SIGINT
description:
In early 2012, Communications Security Establishment Canada analyzed telecommunications flows surrounding Brazil’s Ministry of Mines and Energy. The ministry was described by CSEC as “a new target to develop.” 
 
Codenamed “Olympia,” the suite of analytic tools used by CSEC to parse the ministry’s telephone and Internet use was the subject of a presentation made to allied intelligence analysts inside the United States. 
 
The presentation does not explain the purpose of the CSEC surveillance. 
 
The Globe and Mail is making available a copy of a leaked presentation, in collaboration with Brazil-based American journalist Glenn Greenwald. The document was first acquired by Edward Snowden, a former U.S. National Security Agency contractor.

description: A secret document of former NSA-contractor Edward Snowden shows that the AIVD use a technology called Computer Network Exploitation – CNE – to hack the web fora and collect the data.
